stream_context.summary: Kaze’s stream focused almost entirely on implementing and polishing new ‘Star-Select’ background scenes (animated title-card screens) for Return to Yoshi’s Island. He imported Biobak’s new graphics for Koopa Wave Cove, Mouse Cave, and Bubble Dome, wrote C code to move a minecart model along a spline, battled depth-range and fog issues, and tweaked scrolling textures and animation speeds.

development_findings.summary: Depth values beyond ±33,000 crash real N64 hardware, so Kaze halved the background scale and re-positioned the camera to keep all vertices inside safe bounds.
development_findings.quote: If you render any object out of this range your N64 is just gonna crash.

development_findings.summary: Switching star-select backgrounds to the ‘F3D’ microcode bloats display lists and slows render; Kaze opts for the lighter variant and trims hidden triangles to keep 60 FPS.
development_findings.quote: If you use regular F3D then the display list is a lot bigger and just renders a lot slower.

development_findings.summary: Arctic’s STRM64 tool let them trim unused tail sections of streamed songs, freeing ~1.7 MB of ROM space, so the team can now include more streamed music than planned.
development_findings.quote: Arctic realised yesterday that his tool saves 1.7 MB of ROM space… we are allowed to have more streamed music than we thought.

development_findings.summary: Minecart title card: Kaze abandoned blender-exported keyframes and instead drives the cart along hard-coded spline points, incrementing distance by 80 units per tick for smoother, cheaper animation.
Wheel-scrolling was first done through Fast64 but considered ‘unoptimised’; Kaze replaced it with manual texture-tile offset per frame in code.
Global fog is ‘basically free’ but can hide Z-sorting issues; he adjusted fog distance and added a grey plane attached to the camera to mask pop-in.
He removed unused back-faces and subdivided floor quads in several star-select meshes to save ~80 triangles per screen.
Planned to scroll minecart wheels and tilt the cart based on spline slope; linear interpolation caused perpetual left tilt, so he inverted pitch calculation and tuned speed.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and Zeina are moving into a new house next week; Kaze also started a new job as a 3-D modeler ‘for the government (kind of)’.
YouTube revenue is extremely low (US$6.90 last month) and Patreon only ‘a little’, making the hack effectively non-profitable.
context_findings.quote: My YouTube as it is, is already barely even profitable.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is frustrated by repeated suggestions to use Parallel Launcher/console debug tools, calling them ‘useless’ and refusing to add that dependency.
context_findings.quote: I’m so tired of people trying to tell me to use the weird parallel launcher console debug shit.

biobak.summary: Delivered multiple star-select background models (carnival wave, crystal cave, bubble dome), complete with sketches and animation ideas, and live-fed corrections during stream.
Wants to create Yoshi ‘sticker pack’ art featuring famous Kaze quotes; is also tracking Kaze’s memorable lines.
Half-jokingly quoted ‘$5 per vertex’ payment rate; later mentioned ‘starving’, prompting pay discussion.

zeina.summary: Joined voice chat, brainstormed Yoshi sticker concepts and joked about ‘happy happy cat’ meme; provided informal feedback on star-select aesthetics.

key_stories.title: Minecart Star-Select Challenge
key_stories.summary: Biobak provided a huge minecart model meant to roll behind the menu. Kaze discovered the model exceeded N64’s ±33 k coordinate range, causing potential hardware crashes.
key_stories.challenge: Keep the cinematic minecart idea without exceeding hardware depth limits or tanking FPS.
key_stories.process: Rescaled background by 50 %, repositioned camera, rewrote animation to follow a spline in C, added fog plane, optimised textures and wheel scroll.
key_stories.outcome: Stable 60 FPS star-select screen with scrolling wheels and subtle tilt; further polish (leaves, extra birds) deferred to next stream.
key_stories.key_quote: There’s a very tempting force to just add more and more shit until it’s a cluster-fuck; it kinda ruins the elegance.

key_stories.title: ROM Space Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Arctic noticed many streamed songs contained unused data after loop points.
key_stories.challenge: Running out of ROM space limited how many high-quality tracks could ship.
key_stories.process: Used STRM64 to trim tails, saving 1.7 MB.
key_stories.outcome: Green-light to include more streamed music; Kaze praises Arctic’s discovery.
key_stories.key_quote: There were a few songs that kept going after the loop… we didn’t need that at all.

key_stories.title: Payment Conversation
key_stories.summary: Biobak jokes about ‘$5 per vertex’ and ‘starving’.
key_stories.challenge: Artwork workload increasing while project generates little income.
key_stories.process: Kaze admits limited funds but offers to discuss compensation post-stream.
key_stories.outcome: No agreement yet; illustrates indie-hack financial strain.
key_stories.key_quote: I definitely can’t pay you like a real job, but you should be compensated somewhat.
